# Coming Attractions: An Excellent Event, And An Exciting New Podcast
## Please join us on February 2 for a celebration of the life and legacy of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg.
By [Lateral Link](https://abovethelaw.com/author/lateral-link/)  
onJanuary 22, 2021 at 2:14 PMJanuary 22, 2021 at 3:21 PM
3
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/01/coming-attractions-an-excellent-event-and-an-exciting-new-podcast/&text=Coming%20Attractions:%20An%20Excellent%20Event,%20And%20An%20Exciting%20New%20Podcast)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/01/coming-attractions-an-excellent-event-and-an-exciting-new-podcast/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/01/coming-attractions-an-excellent-event-and-an-exciting-new-podcast/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg (Photo by Nikki Kahn/The Washington Post via Getty Images)

Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg and her husband, Marty Ginsburg, modeled a true partnership in pursuit of gender equity. Their commitment to equal justice pervaded their personal and professional lives and will have a lasting impact on the legal profession and our society. To honor their legacy, the [Center for Women in Law](https://law.utexas.edu/cwil/) at the University of Texas School of Law is proud to announce the [Ginsburg Initiative](https://law.utexas.edu/cwil/ginsburg-initiative/), which will advance gender-neutral initiatives that support systemic change, such as best practices surrounding work assignments, performance expectations, parental leave, and transparency in career development.

On Tuesday, February 2, to mark the launch of the Ginsburg Initiative, the Center will host a virtual panel discussion on the life and legacy of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, which Lateral Link is proud to sponsor. The panel discussion will be moderated by Nina Totenberg — NPR’s celebrated legal affairs correspondent, as well as a [longtime friend of Justice Ginsburg](https://www.npr.org/2020/09/19/896733375/a-five-decade-long-friendship-that-began-with-a-phone-call) — and will feature four former RBG clerks:

- [Ryan Park](https://ncdoj.gov/attorney-general-josh-stein-announces-transitions-in-solicitor-generals-office/), Solicitor General, the State of North Carolina;
- [Alexandra A.E. Shapiro](https://www.shapiroarato.com/person/alexandra-shapiro/), Partner, Shapiro Arato Bach;
- [Amanda Tyler](https://www.law.berkeley.edu/our-faculty/faculty-profiles/amanda-tyler/), Shannon Cecil Turner Professor of Law, UC Berkeley School of Law; and
- The Honorable [Paul J. Watford](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_J._Watford), Judge, U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
The event is free and open to the public, and it has been approved for 1.25 hours of CLE credit (in Texas and reciprocal jurisdictions). Please [register here](https://utexas.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_XFEXqqWgQKmAdyOx9TlrRw?utm_source=Master+List-Alum+and+PR%2FSummit+Attendee&utm_campaign=63c7bdddc6-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2020_03_03_04_13_COPY_02&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_6bc543fc6c-63c7bdddc6-333836808) for what will surely be a fascinating discussion about one of the most important and groundbreaking figures in American history.

Meanwhile, here at Lateral Link we have been working on the development of a new podcast focused on the Biglaw lateral market, entitled “Movers, Shakers, and Rainmakers.” Each week, my colleague [Zach Sandberg](https://www.laterallink.com/team/zach-sandberg/) and I will dissect some of the most significant recent lateral partner moves, discuss important trends in the legal market, and provide you with the news you need to know about the ever-changing ecosystem of the world’s largest law firms. If you have suggestions for topics or guests for the podcast, please reach out [to me](mailto:dlat@laterallink.com?subject=Podcast%20Idea) or [to Zach](mailto:mailto:zsandberg@laterallink.com?subject=Podcast%20Idea).

We look forward to hearing from you, and we look forward to seeing you on February 2!

Ed. note: This is the latest installment in a series of posts from [Lateral Link’s](http://laterallink.com/) team of expert contributors. This post is by [David Lat](https://www.laterallink.com/team/david-lat/), a managing director in the New York office, where he focuses on placing top associates, partners and partner groups into preeminent law firms around the country.

Prior to joining Lateral Link, David founded and served as managing editor of Above the Law. Prior to launching Above the Law, he worked as a federal prosecutor, a litigation associate at Wachtell Lipton Rosen & Katz in New York, and a law clerk to Judge Diarmuid F. O’Scannlain of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. David is a graduate of Harvard College and Yale Law School. You can connect with David on [Twitter (@DavidLat)](http://bit.ly/2BMTF1R), [LinkedIn](http://bit.ly/2E9v0tq), and [Facebook](http://bit.ly/2nxIENN), and you can reach him by email at [dlat@laterallink.com](mailto:dlat@laterallink.com).

[Lateral Link](http://laterallink.com/) is one of the top-rated international legal recruiting firms. With over 14 offices worldwide, Lateral Link specializes in placing attorneys at the most prestigious law firms and companies in the world. Managed by former practicing attorneys from top law schools, Lateral Link has a tradition of hiring lawyers to execute the lateral leaps of practicing attorneys. Click [here](https://www.laterallink.com/clients-testimonials/) to find out more about us.

####Topics

Watford](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/paul-j-watford/), [Paul Watford](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/paul-watford/), [Podcasts](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/podcasts/), [Ruth Bader Ginsburg](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/ruth-bader-ginsburg/), [Ryan Park](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/ryan-park/), [Sponsored Content](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/sponsored-content/)

[Morning Docket](https://abovethelaw.com/morning-docket/)
# Morning Docket: 09.17.19
## * Faster lawyers don't necessarily mean better lawyers sounds like something a client would say just before demanding an overnight answer. [[Law.com](https://www.law.com/2019/09/17/as-legal-business-moves-faster-lawyers-aim-to-manage-client-expectations/)] * Jurists rallying behind judge charged with obstruction for not letting ICE demean the judicial system by turning it into stakeout location. [[National Law Journal](https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/2019/09/16/61-retired-jurists-support-judge-charged-with-helping-man-escape-ice-arrest/)] * Prosecutors seek 15 year sentence for Manafort's former son-in-law. Maybe Skadden can write a report justifying his actions? [[Politico](https://www.politico.com/story/2019/09/16/manafort-jeffrey-yohai-1498903)] * Shenzhen is coming and Biglaw has a new market to figure out. [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2019/09/16/will-shenzhen-become-the-new-hong-kong-405-44398/)] * JP Morgan traders accused of 8-year racket. This is in contrast to the more broadly defined 220-year racket the company's been up to. [[Law360](https://www.law360.com/corporate/articles/1198568/3-jpmorgan-traders-accused-of-8-year-spoofing-racket)] * White House ordering more people to ignore subpoenas, so that's a super development for the rule of law. [[Courthouse News Service](https://www.courthousenews.com/white-house-orders-2-former-aides-to-defy-house-subpoenas/)] * While the UK endures a constitutional meltdown, here are fun facts about their Supreme Court. [[Legal Cheek](https://www.legalcheek.com/2019/09/legal-twitterati-share-their-hilarious-supremecourtfacts-as-prorogation-of-parliament-case-gets-underway/)]
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onSeptember 17, 2019 at 8:31 AM
0

# The Partners' Secret Truths
## How do partners decide which associates will work on their cases? Find out.
By [Mark Herrmann](https://abovethelaw.com/author/mark-herrmann/)  
onOctober 22, 2018 at 10:03 AMOctober 21, 2018 at 1:26 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/10/the-partners-secret-truths/&text=The%20Partners’%20Secret%20Truths)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/10/the-partners-secret-truths/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/10/the-partners-secret-truths/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The junior partner was elated:  “I just landed a big case in Los Angeles!”

The senior partner was much calmer:  “Congratulations.  How do you plan to staff it?”

“I’m going to call the head of the LA office this afternoon and ask for help.”

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
“Are you nuts?”

“What?”

“Don’t call the head of the LA office.  The head of the LA office has one objective:  To keep everyone in LA busy, so the office looks good at the end of the year.  When you ask the head of the LA office for help, he’ll find the one lawyer who has nothing to do, and he’ll assign that lawyer to your case, to keep the lawyer busy.”

“So?”

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)

### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
“Any associate in this firm who’s any good has too much work to do.  Partners are fighting for the associate’s time.  The person with nothing to do is terrible.  He produces garbage, so nobody wants to use him.  That’s why he’s sitting around twiddling his thumbs.  Call the head of the LA office to ask for help, and that’s the person who’ll be assigned to your case.”

“What should I do?”

“Is there anyone you know and trust in LA?  Call someone in LA who you personally know and trust.  Ask that person to recommend a good associate to you.  Then call the associate directly, and entice the associate to work on your new matter.  Whatever you do, don’t call the head of the office.”

“I never would have thought of that.  Thanks for the suggestion.”

“No problem.  By the way, who are you using here in Chicago for help on your new case?”

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)

From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)

[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
“I’m using [Jarndyce](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jarndyce_and_Jarndyce).  Jarndyce helped me on my last case, and she was spectacular.  I’m asking her to help again.”

“Is Jarndyce really good?”

“Terrific.  She’s one of the best associates I’ve ever worked with.”

“You’d better keep that under your hat.”

“Huh?”

“If you ever find any associates who are worth a damn, you don’t want your partners to know the associates’ names.  Your partners will steal those people from you.”

“Huh?”

“The average associate around here is average.  That’s not very good.  No partner wants typical associates working on the partner’s cases.  Partners wants the few great associates that we have, so the partners are able to produce great quality work for their clients.  If you ever stumble onto associates who are good, the last thing you want is for everybody else to know their names.”

“Can I ever tell anyone that associates are good?”

“Sure — at review time.  When we’re reviewing associates, you want our management to know which are the quality associates, and you want to help the careers of those people.  But that’s it.  Otherwise, tell people you don’t know any good associates — or tell people that the bad associates are good.”

“How long have you been working here at Bigg & Mediocre?”

“Ever since I graduated from law school 25 years ago. Trust me.  I’ve seen a lot.”

Mark Herrmann spent 17 years as a partner at a leading international law firm and is now deputy general counsel at a large international company. He is the author of [The Curmudgeon’s Guide to Practicing Law](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1590316762/ref=as_li_ss_tl?ie=UTF8&tag=dealbreaker-20&linkCode=as2&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=1590316762) and [Inside Straight: Advice About Lawyering, In-House And Out, That Only The Internet Could Provide](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1614385394/ref=as_li_ss_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=1614385394&linkCode=as2&tag=dealbreaker-20) (affiliate links). You can reach him by email at [inhouse@abovethelaw.com](mailto:inhouse@abovethelaw.com).

# Biglaw Firm Gets To The Business Of Raises AND High Biller Bonuses
## Happy (money) days are here again.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJuly 6, 2021 at 11:15 AMJuly 6, 2021 at 11:02 AM
14
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/winston-raises/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Gets%20To%20The%20Business%20Of%20Raises%20AND%20High%20Biller%20Bonuses)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/winston-raises/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/winston-raises/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Good times are back for folks at Winston & Strawn! After what could be characterized as a bumpy 2020 (and really, whose 2020 wasn’t — at least at times — shit) the firm’s back to handing out the big bucks to associates.

[Back in September of 2020, we reported](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/associate-layoffs-and-staff-cuts-come-to-am-law-50-biglaw-firm/) that the firm, ranked #45 on the latest Am Law 100 list, was letting go a number of associates and staff, and that was after they’d already[ cut partner compensation](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/am-law-top-50-firm-cuts-partner-compensation-in-half-over-covid-19-concerns/) as part of their COVID-19 austerity measures. But we are very much in the “post” now, and Winston’s fortunes have turned around.

[In December](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/12/winston-2020-bonuses/), the firm handed out market bonuses, and also got on the [special bonus train ](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/winston-special-bonuses/)earlier this year (and also announced an increase to the firm’s high biller pool), so things are very much back to normal at the firm. On June 11, they quickly matched the Milbank scale, but now that the slightly higher DPW scale is dominating the industry, they’re ready to match that as well.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)

The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  


You can read the [full memo on the next page](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/winston-raises/2/).

Plus, remember those increased high biller bonuses? The firm announced more details on those. The pool is anticipated to be at least 75 percent larger, and they’ll kick in at 2,100 hours (which is lower than the historical threshold). The scale of those bonuses is as follows:

# Morning Docket: 08.24.17
## * Appellate court rules that Facebook friends aren't necessarily "friends." If they're in your Top 8 on MySpace on the other hand.... [[Law.com](http://www.law.com/sites/almstaff/2017/08/23/judges-facebook-friendship-with-attorney-doesnt-require-recusal-court-rules/)] * Guy drove a car into a crowd holding vigil over a trans woman killed by police. But, you know, there was violence on both sides... many sides. [[Huffington Post](http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/trans-vigil-car-hits-protesters_us_599e4288e4b06d67e3351ccc/)] * Can this lawyer achieve Middle East peace? Nope. [[NBC News](https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/can-trump-s-ex-lawyer-jason-greenblatt-achieve-middle-east-n786671)] * Texas courts strike down the state's latest voter suppression effort. [[Politico](http://www.politico.com/story/2017/08/23/texas-identification-voters-voting-241962)] * The CFPB goes easier on those that self-report. In a functioning justice and regulatory system that's true of every government agency, but these days that's newsworthy. [[National Law Journal](http://www.nationallawjournal.com/id=1202796305588/)] * Partner pink slips abound in advance of Biglaw mergers. [[Am Law Daily](http://www.americanlawyer.com/id=1202796256196/Two-Big-Law-Firms-Shed-Partners-Ahead-of-Mergers/)] * Second Circuit ends the Newman relationship test. New York defense lawyers respond with "What, me worry?" [[Law360](https://www.law360.com/newyork/articles/957178/2nd-circ-ends-newman-relationship-test-but-for-how-long-/)]

# Unlike Most Other Biglaw Firms, Cravath Bucks The Trend Of Record Partnership Class Sizes
## An interesting announcement as Biglaw bonus season is set to begin.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onNovember 18, 2021 at 3:15 PMNovember 19, 2021 at 11:29 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/unlike-most-other-biglaw-firms-cravath-bucks-the-trend-of-record-partnership-class-sizes/&text=Unlike%20Most%20Other%20Biglaw%20Firms,%20Cravath%20Bucks%20The%20Trend%20Of%20Record%20Partnership%20Class%20Sizes)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/unlike-most-other-biglaw-firms-cravath-bucks-the-trend-of-record-partnership-class-sizes/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/unlike-most-other-biglaw-firms-cravath-bucks-the-trend-of-record-partnership-class-sizes/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Thanks to the hot lateral market, Biglaw firms are handing out partnership offers like candy, perhaps as a way to keep their best associates from fleeing to another firm. Biglaw firms have continuously announced [record partnership class sizes](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/biglaw-firms-scared-of-losing-associates-are-making-them-partner/) in response to the ongoing talent war, but one prestigious firm doesn’t seem interested in keeping up with the Kirklands (a firm where a record [151 lawyers](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/10/worlds-wealthiest-law-firm-announces-colossal-partner-class/) were elevated to partner).

It was just last year that Cravath boasted one of its largest partnership classes in recent memory — and its [most diverse partnership class](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/10/cravath-makes-history-in-diversity-with-its-new-partnership-class/?rf=1) in history — by promoting 11 associates. This year, the firm [returned to its old ways](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2021/11/18/a-year-after-largest-partner-class-ever-cravath-returns-to-5-year-average/), inviting six associates to become members of its partnership. Cravath has had a 6.4 new partners per-year average over the course of the past five years.

It was July when we wondered if the pandemic had [broken the Cravath system](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/07/did-the-pandemic-break-the-cravath-system/). After all, the firm that typically shies away from laterals was hiring an “attorney talent recruitment manager.” Back then, the firm was willing to join the crusade to gobble up laterals but now it seems to be bucking the Biglaw trend of making partnership promotions en masse.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
What other trends will Cravath be willing to buck?

Biglaw is on the precipice of 2021’s year-end bonus season, and after a year marked by bonuses upon bonuses upon bonuses, associates across the country are waiting and watching to see what Cravath will do. The firm was once the market leader for salaries and bonuses, but has allowed others to take the lead in recent years. Associates think it’s time for a change — and a big one, at that.

The $15,000 to $100,000 seniority-based bonus scale has been in place for years on end. Will Cravath step up to the plate, retake its place at the top of the compensation ladder, and offer associates more money? We suppose we’ll soon see.

Congratulations to Cravath’s new partners!

# Now That Abortion Rights Have Been Decimated, Biglaw Leader Offers Heartfelt Message Of Support For Lawyers
## This is the perfect example of what Biglaw firms can do to help their attorneys right now.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 24, 2022 at 1:13 PMJune 24, 2022 at 2:35 PM
33
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/now-that-abortion-rights-have-been-decimated-biglaw-leader-offers-heartfelt-message-of-support-for-lawyers/&text=Now%20That%20Abortion%20Rights%20Have%20Been%20Decimated,%20Biglaw%20Leader%20Offers%20Heartfelt%20Message%20Of%20Support%20For%20Lawyers)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/now-that-abortion-rights-have-been-decimated-biglaw-leader-offers-heartfelt-message-of-support-for-lawyers/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/now-that-abortion-rights-have-been-decimated-biglaw-leader-offers-heartfelt-message-of-support-for-lawyers/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Now that the Supreme Court has laid waste to nearly 50 years of precedent by overturning Roe v. Wade with its decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health, attorneys have been left wondering what comes next. For many, it’s a truly depressing day to be a lawyer in America. How can we possibly reconcile the destruction of the fundamental right to choose against the fractured political framework that seeks to deny our reproductive freedom? When your bodily autonomy is under attack, it’s incredibly distracting, to say the very least.

While some firms have released statements reminding associates that they should [try to be collegial](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/abortion-rights-are-about-to-be-destroyed-so-biglaw-firm-piles-on-the-bullsht/) during these divisive times, others are making their priorities known, and the contrast is stark.

[Julie Jones](https://www.ropesgray.com/en/biographies/j/julie-h-jones), the chair of Ropes & Gray, released the following statement just minutes after the Supreme Court released its opinion in Dobbs. We will let the statement speak for itself. Please let it serve as a lesson on what Biglaw leaders across the country can do guide their attorneys in times like these.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
This morning, the U.S. Supreme Court issued its decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health, ending 50 years of federal constitutional protection of abortion rights.  The Dobbs ruling has created extraordinarily strong feelings in many of us.  As a lawyer, I reflect on Supreme Court jurisprudence, the principle of stare decisis and the future of privacy rights and other civil right protections in the United States.   As a woman, I have a profound feeling of vulnerability caused by the elimination of a long-standing right of women – a right that affects their bodies and their agency.  As a person with privilege, I recognize and worry about the decision’s disproportionate impact on women with limited resources.   As an American, I fear the divisive nature of this topic will further fracture an already angry and divided citizenry. As a leader of Ropes & Gray, I am concerned about the effect of this decision on our community.  We have strong, principled and differing beliefs on abortion rights within the firm; even in our very respectful community, internal dialogue about the Dobbs decision and its consequences could be imbued with bitterness. This very writing, which I undertook because of the gravity of the moment, carries the likelihood of offense to portions of our community who, for a variety of reasons, favored the reversal of Roe v. Wade.  

While I don’t have answers about the future direction of the Court’s decisions or how to heal a divided citizenry, I do know that at moments where so many colleagues are hurting and need support, the Ropes & Gray community stands tall for each other.  To that end, we will be holding two community gatherings over the next few days.   The Women’s Forum will host a meeting for all interested colleagues – to offer the comfort of community and a forum for conversation in small breakout groups.  In a second gathering, Doug Hallward-Driemeier will lead an overview of federal and state law on reproductive rights post-Dobbs.    

Ropes & Gray has long dedicated itself to the protection of civil rights and individual liberties – whether those rights are grounded in federal, state or local law.  We will remain steadfast in that mission in the weeks and months to come.  Anticipating today’s decision, many of you have reached out to the head of our pro bono program, Roz Nasdor, and our U.S. pro bono committee chairs, Jenny Rikoski and Chris Conniff, to ask how you can channel your concern into action.   There will be many opportunities for those interested to contribute on a pro bono basis to the protection of health care rights for women, a cause which Ropes & Gray will continue to champion.

# Secret Service Agents On Arnold & Porter Associate's Detail Fired Shots During Attempted Car Break-In
## That associate is also the president's granddaughter, so that explains a lot.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onNovember 13, 2023 at 12:15 PMNovember 13, 2023 at 12:52 PM
16
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/secret-service-agents-on-arnold-porter-associates-detail-shots-fired-during-attempted-car-break-in/&text=Secret%20Service%20Agents%20On%20Arnold%20&%20Porter%20Associate’s%20Detail%20Fired%20Shots%20During%20Attempted%20Car%20Break-In)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/secret-service-agents-on-arnold-porter-associates-detail-shots-fired-during-attempted-car-break-in/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/secret-service-agents-on-arnold-porter-associates-detail-shots-fired-during-attempted-car-break-in/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Naomi Biden and her Pop. (Photo by Ng Han Guan-Pool/Getty Images)

President Joe Biden’s granddaughter, Naomi Biden, is an [associate at Arnold & Porter](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/12/biden-granddaughter-to-join-d-c-biglaw-firm/), and accordingly, has a Secret Service detail (for that first part, not because she’s a Biglaw associate). Over the weekend, those agents were called into action when they witnessed three individuals trying to break into an unmarked Secret Service vehicle.

As [reported by](https://www.huffpost.com/entry/secret-service-agents-shoot-naomi-biden-car_n_65522920e4b09c9500ab193e) the Associated Press, the incident took place on Sunday night in the Georgetown neighborhood. One agent discharged their weapon, but it is not believed that anyone was injured.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
One of the agents opened fire, but no one was struck by the gunfire, the Secret Service said in a statement. The three people were seen fleeing in a red car, and the Secret Service said it put out a regional bulletin to Metropolitan Police to be on the lookout for it.

Our preliminary statement on the weapon discharge following a break-in to a Secret Service vehicle. Two to Three possible suspects fled the scene in a vehicle and a regional bulletin has been issued to supporting units. [@DCPoliceDept](https://twitter.com/DCPoliceDept?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw) are investigating the incident. [pic.twitter.com/lECykumT2s](https://t.co/lECykumT2s)

— Anthony Guglielmi (@SecretSvcSpox) [November 13, 2023](https://twitter.com/SecretSvcSpox/status/1724057404822675924?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw)

It isn’t known if Naomi Biden heard the incident as it developed outside.

# Top 30 Biglaw Firm Sends Bonuses To The Moon For Associates With Sky-High Billable Hours
## Big money for the firm's biggest billers!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onDecember 21, 2021 at 12:00 PMDecember 21, 2021 at 10:52 AM
3
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/quinn-bonus-2021/&text=Top%2030%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Sends%20Bonuses%20To%20The%20Moon%20For%20Associates%20With%20Sky-High%20Billable%20Hours)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/quinn-bonus-2021/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/quinn-bonus-2021/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Some elite Biglaw firms are known for offering market-beating bonuses for their biggest billers. Year after year, they prove that they’re willing to pay for the most committed legal talent by adding tens of thousands of dollars to their regular year-end bonus payouts.

One of those firms is Quinn Emanuel.

Hot on the heels of announcing that it would allow its lawyers to [work remotely, indefinitely](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/quinn-emanuel-will-allow-lawyers-to-work-remotely-indefinitely-from-anywhere-in-the-country/), from anywhere in the country, the top 30 Am Law firm unveiled its 2021 bonus matrix. As usual, there are some pretty big rewards in store for those who truly dedicated their lives to the firm.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Associates who billed between 2100 and 2399 hours will receive a bonus equal to the market rate (the original [Cravath year-end bonus](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/11/first-mover-on-bonus/) with the [Davis Polk special bonus](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/davis-polk-bonuses-21/) on top). Big billers start raking in more cash at 2400 hours. Depending on class year, those who billed 2400 hours or more will receive up to $23,000 more than market, while those who billed 2700 hours or more will receive up to $40,250 more than market, not including special bonuses.

Check out the Quinn Emanuel matrix below:



This year, the firm is offering partial bonuses to those who had hours between 2000-2099, and as usual, the firm is rounding associates up to market bonuses if they just missed the 2100 cutoff, with special bonuses “paid proportionally” to those who missed the 2100-hour mark.

# Leading Los Angeles Law Firm FINALLY Shows Associates The Money!
## This firm finally got with the program and gave its associates the raises they deserved.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 13, 2016 at 6:55 PMJune 13, 2016 at 7:10 PM
17
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/leading-los-angeles-law-firm-finally-shows-associates-the-money/&text=Leading%20Los%20Angeles%20Law%20Firm%20FINALLY%20Shows%20Associates%20The%20Money!)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/leading-los-angeles-law-firm-finally-shows-associates-the-money/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/leading-los-angeles-law-firm-finally-shows-associates-the-money/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
“Why haven’t we heard anything from Gibson Dunn? This is insulting.”

“You need to call out Gibson Dunn. Absurd!!!”

“Now that literally all of our peer firms have matched nationwide, associates at GDC are becoming irate.”

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
“You need to shame Gibson Dunn into matching Cravath. We’ve had enough waiting.”

That’s just a smattering of what we’d heard from readers about Gibson Dunn. Considering the fact that the firm places [just outside the Top 10 in Vault’s rankings](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/which-vault-top-25-firms-have-not-yet-announced-raises/2/), associates were pretty pissed off when they heard nothing but silence with regard to matching the now-prevailing $180K salary scale that’s been adopted throughout top-tier Biglaw firms. Don’t worry, associates, you needn’t be irate anymore.

Today, Gibson Dunn has finally decided to match the market. [Kenneth Doran](http://www.gibsondunn.com/lawyers/kdoran), the firm’s managing partner, said in an email addressed to all associates that this move was “[i]n keeping with our commitment to pay competitive compensation to our associates.” Gibson has matched the Cravath scale for all classes through 2008, and will be matching the Cravath scale for incoming associates in the class of 2016 as well. Associates in the following locations will receive a raise: Los Angeles, CA; Century City, CA; Orange County, CA; Palo Alto, CA; San Francisco, CA; New York, NY; Dallas, TX; Denver, CO; and Washington, D.C. Unfortunately, there is no mention of how current summer associates’ compensation will be affected in the memo.

Congratulations to all Gibson Dunn associates! You finally got what you wanted!

# The First Ever Woman To Lead A Biglaw Firm
## She's pretty impressive.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onNovember 13, 2018 at 5:17 PMNovember 14, 2018 at 9:39 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/the-first-ever-woman-to-lead-a-biglaw-firm/&text=The%20First%20Ever%20Woman%20To%20Lead%20A%20Biglaw%20Firm)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/the-first-ever-woman-to-lead-a-biglaw-firm/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/the-first-ever-woman-to-lead-a-biglaw-firm/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))


In 1998, what firm became the first in the Am Law 100 to have a woman as the head of the firm?

Hint: She was 42 when she became Chair of the firm, which also makes her one of the youngest Biglaw executives too.

# Apparently Some People DON'T Think You Should Be Charged With Manslaughter For Getting Shot In The Stomach
## How bad? Worse than the New York Mets bad.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJuly 1, 2019 at 2:14 PMJuly 1, 2019 at 1:41 PM
51
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/07/apparently-some-people-dont-think-you-should-be-charged-with-manslaughter-for-getting-shot-in-the-stomach/&text=Apparently%20Some%20People%20DON’T%20Think%20You%20Should%20Be%20Charged%20With%20Manslaughter%20For%20Getting%20Shot%20In%20The%20Stomach)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/07/apparently-some-people-dont-think-you-should-be-charged-with-manslaughter-for-getting-shot-in-the-stomach/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/07/apparently-some-people-dont-think-you-should-be-charged-with-manslaughter-for-getting-shot-in-the-stomach/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Marshae Jones

The New York Mets in their worst season didn’t have as many errors as this indictment.

— Mark White, of White Arnold & Dowd, representing Marshae Jones told [AL.com](https://www.al.com/news/2019/06/motion-to-dismiss-marshae-jones-charge-to-be-filed-monday-attorney-says.html) he will be filing a motion to dismiss the charges against his client. Jones’s criminal case rose to national prominence when Alabama indicted her for her fetus’s death after she was shot and the charges against the shooter were dropped. Jones’s case has been a [source of outrage](https://jezebel.com/alabama-woman-indicted-after-someone-else-shoots-her-in-1835892341) for those that see this as a dystopian extension of Alabama’s anti-choice laws. White went on to say “It appears that someone who should’ve been objective decided to frame the narrative for their own personal political reasons.” He also noted Jones’s case was an “unprecedented, inappropriate charge that is not permitted under that the law in Alabama.”

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, and host of [The Jabot podcast.](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA) AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](https://twitter.com/Kathryn1)).

####Topics
[Alabama](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/alabama/), [Marshae Jones](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/marshae-jones/), [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/), [Reproductive Freedom](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/reproductive-freedom/), [The Jabot](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/the-jabot/)

### [ How Will Walgreens’ Expansion Into Specialty Pharmacy Affect The Industry? ](https://medcitynews.com/2024/04/walgreens-specialty-pharmacy-drugs/)
Walgreens announced that it is expanding its specialty pharmacy offerings. Experts think that this move could yield several strategic benefits, given the higher profit margins associated with specialty medications compared to traditional drugs. They also think Walgreens’ move could lead to greater competition, consolidation, and innovation within the broader pharmacy industry.

# This Lawyer Built A Biglaw Firm Serving The Spanish Speaking Immigrant Community (Hint: Not Aaron Schlossberg)
## Nearly 100 years ago, there were lawyers with better attitudes about speaking Spanish.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onMay 24, 2018 at 4:58 PMMay 24, 2018 at 4:20 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/this-lawyer-built-a-biglaw-firm-serving-the-spanish-speaking-immigrant-community-hint-not-aaron-schlossberg/&text=This%20Lawyer%20Built%20A%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Serving%20The%20Spanish%20Speaking%20Immigrant%20Community%20(Hint:%20Not%20Aaron%20Schlossberg))[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/this-lawyer-built-a-biglaw-firm-serving-the-spanish-speaking-immigrant-community-hint-not-aaron-schlossberg/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/this-lawyer-built-a-biglaw-firm-serving-the-spanish-speaking-immigrant-community-hint-not-aaron-schlossberg/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))


While [Aaron Schlossberg](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/aaron-schlossberg-is-having-a-delightfully-bad-day/) may not appreciate people speaking Spanish in America, which firm’s named founder built an elite powerhouse providing legal services to Chicago’s then-growing Mexican American community in 1925?

Hint: The lawyer would parlay his Spanish skills into advising American companies investing in Latin America.

# Morning Docket: 06.02.16
## * A judge has ruled that Andrew Schmuhl, the attorney accused of torturing and nearly killing the managing partner of the law firm his wife was fired from, will not be allowed to use an involuntary intoxication defense at trial. We may have more on this later today. [[Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/true-crime/wp/2016/06/01/judge-rules-out-involuntary-intoxication-defense-in-mclean-home-invasion-trial/)] * Congratulations to Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg! A newly discovered species of praying mantis with a decorative neck plate, the Ilomantis ginsburgae, has been named after Her Honor thanks to her "commitment to women's rights and gender equality... and her appreciation of the jabot." This is an honor that is truly fitting for the Notorious R.B.G. [[New York Magazine](http://nymag.com/thecut/2016/06/praying-mantis-named-after-ruth-bader-ginsburg.html)] * Partners continue to head for the exits at Kenyon & Kenyon. This time, the chair of the IP firm's life sciences and chemical prosecution practice fled for Fox Rothschild, and he took two others with him. What's going on as this firm, and did they decide finally decide to officially pull the plug on the summer program? Let us know. [[Big Law Business](https://bol.bna.com/three-more-exits-at-kenyon-kenyon-no-word-from-colbert/)] * "There's absolutely no showing of any federal violation. The citizens of California are smart enough to know what their rights are." Sorry, Bernie bros, but because unaffiliated voters' rights haven't been harmed, voter registration will not be reopened ahead of next week's primary in the Golden State. Best of luck in the polls. [[Los Angeles Times](http://www.latimes.com/politics/la-pol-ca-voting-lawsuit-sanders-supporters-20160601-snap-story.html)] * People are still raging against this JOP: The Nevada Attorneys for Criminal Justice, a group of defense lawyers 150 strong, have filed an ethics complaint against Judge Conrad Hafen, saying he showed a "complete disregard for the law" when he handcuffed a public defender as she tried to represent her client. [[Las Vegas Review-Journal](http://www.reviewjournal.com/news/las-vegas/ethics-complaint-filed-against-las-vegas-judge-who-had-lawyer-handcuffed)] * Boyce Martin Jr., chief judge emeritus of the Sixth Circuit, RIP. [[Courier-Journal](http://www.courier-journal.com/story/news/local/2016/06/01/boyce-martin-jr-giant-bench-has-died/83038734/)]
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 2, 2016 at 8:59 AMJune 1, 2016 at 8:23 PM
7

# Morning Docket: 09.13.16
## * Green Party presidential nominee Dr. Jill Stein will appear at Vermont Law School today, where she'll meet with members of the law school community to speak about her plan to transition the country using 100 percent renewable energy. Law students will be especially excited to hear about her plans to cancel all student loan debt. [[VTDigger](https://vtdigger.org/2016/09/12/presidential-candidate-stein-set-speak-vermont-law-school-tuesday/)] * “Talk to your classmates, especially those with different views. Even if you come away from it disagreeing even more, at least you know what makes them tick, which is a useful thing.” Last week, Justice Elena Kagan went back to Harvard Law, the school where she once served as dean, to share helpful tips with law students. [[Harvard Crimson](http://www.thecrimson.com/article/2016/9/9/justice-kagan-addresses-law-students/)] * Federal prosecutors may have dropped their corruption case against ex-Gov. Bob McDonnell after SCOTUS threw out his convictions, but now he's got some pretty hefty legal bills to pay to Jones Day and Holland & Knight. Right now, he owes more than $10M to the partners who helped clear his name. [[Richmond Times-Dispatch](http://www.richmond.com/news/virginia/government-politics/article_bcfe6873-dd0f-535f-a2a1-927782b02659.html?mode=jqm)] * A lot of big-time lateral moves were announced yesterday, including Kirkland & Ellis's mass hiring of all Bancroft lawyers, but Gibson Dunn's news may top all the rest we've yet to cover. Stuart Delery, the former acting associate attorney general of the Justice Department, will join the firm as a partner in Washington, D.C. [[Big Law Business](https://bol.bna.com/place-your-vote-for-the-days-biggest-lateral-hire/)] * Ex-Canadian prime minister Stephen Harper has found a new home -- or rather, a "strategic affiliation" -- with a global Biglaw firm. He'll be working out of the Calgary office of Dentons, where he'll work with many former colleagues and advise firm clients on market access, managing global geopolitical, and economic risk. [[Huffington Post](http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2016/09/12/international-law-firm-dentons-hires-former-prime-minister-stephen-harper_n_11974140.html)]
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onSeptember 13, 2016 at 8:59 AMSeptember 13, 2016 at 1:45 PM
9
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/morning-docket-09-13-16/&text=Morning%20Docket:%2009.13.16)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/morning-docket-09-13-16/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/morning-docket-09-13-16/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

# Biglaw Salary Cuts Might Not Be Enough To Keep Layoffs At Bay
## This is unsettling news.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMay 18, 2020 at 3:15 PMMay 18, 2020 at 2:12 PM
3
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/05/biglaw-salary-cuts-might-not-be-enough-to-keep-layoffs-at-bay/&text=Biglaw%20Salary%20Cuts%20Might%20Not%20Be%20Enough%20To%20Keep%20Layoffs%20At%20Bay)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/05/biglaw-salary-cuts-might-not-be-enough-to-keep-layoffs-at-bay/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/05/biglaw-salary-cuts-might-not-be-enough-to-keep-layoffs-at-bay/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
[W]hile salary cuts shore up a firm’s finances, they don’t fix the underlying problem: too many lawyers, specifically more lawyers than can be kept growing professionally at the required pace given the volume of work available to them. With the level of U.S. economic activity not expected to regain its Q4 2019 level until the first half of 2022, this is more than a short-term challenge. Unchecked, it creates a post-recession existential risk for firms: clients decamping to rivals to avoid being served by under-experienced associate cohorts. Hence, we should expect layoffs when lawyers return to their offices (you can’t reasonably lay someone off over Zoom).

— [Hugh A. Simons](https://twitter.com/simonshugh?lang=en), formerly a senior partner and executive committee member at The Boston Consulting Group and chief operating officer and policy committee member at Ropes & Gray, arguing salary cuts may not be enough for some law firms, and that [layoffs — and even closures — may be coming](https://www.law.com/2020/05/15/as-salary-cuts-move-to-higher-profit-firms-what-happens-next/) down the line. As he notes in his well-reasoned essay, “There’s a new class of associates set to arrive (averaging 6-7 percent of lawyer headcount) and voluntary attrition has gone to zero (as it does in any recession). It will be ugly.”

# Firm Pays Sub-Market Bonuses And Associates Are... Cool With It?
## There's more to life than money.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onDecember 21, 2018 at 4:16 PMDecember 21, 2018 at 12:51 PM
18
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/firm-pays-sub-market-bonuses-and-associates-are-cool-with-it/&text=Firm%20Pays%20Sub-Market%20Bonuses%20And%20Associates%20Are…%20Cool%20With%20It?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/firm-pays-sub-market-bonuses-and-associates-are-cool-with-it/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/firm-pays-sub-market-bonuses-and-associates-are-cool-with-it/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Most of our coverage of “market” compensation tracks the New York Biglaw scale. That’s the most elite American legal market and it’s where the top talent — all else equal — tends to flow. Those salaries generate the most excitement because everyone judges themselves based on where they pay relative to that high water mark.

In 2016, firms all over the country fell all over themselves to match that compensation structure. It’s how we ended up with associates in Charlotte able to buy mansions with New York paychecks.

Locke Lord just walked around its bonuses for the year and they are not matching the “market.” Top billers at some levels will be seeing a match, but generally, Locke Lord’s bonuses seem to be missing the Cravath scale generally by about 25-30 percent by our estimation based on a limited sample size.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Some might cry foul over this disparate treatment, but one associate with a well-developed sense of the big picture sent us this testimonial:

I think every time this time of year comes along there’s a twinge of jealousy for our NY brethren who get larger bonuses in the lockstep manner, but after about 30 seconds, I pack up to head home at a reasonable hour, in a nice car with no debt, to a house that I can easily afford, to a spouse who can work out of enjoyment rather than as a necessity, to talk about whether we should invest or donate most of the bonus because law school debt has already been paid off, and I say “God bless Texas and God bless Locke Lord.”

There’s more to the legal life than money. And there’s a lot more to life when you remember that even these “small” bonuses are still tens of thousands of dollars.

Please help us help you when it comes to bonus news at other firms. As soon as your firm’s bonus memo comes out, please [email it to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Bonus”) or text us (646-820-8477). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onApril 4, 2024 at 5:04 PMApril 4, 2024 at 4:18 PM
1

# Burford Capital Seeks Director Of Case Management In Exclusive Engagement With Lateral Link
## Explore an unparalleled opportunity as Director of Case Management at Burford Capital, steering complex litigation cases with a global leader.
By [LATERAL LINK](https://laterallink.com/)  
onFebruary 2, 2024 at 11:47 AMFebruary 2, 2024 at 12:26 PM
26
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/02/burford-capital-seeks-director-of-case-management-in-exclusive-engagement-with-lateral-link/&text=Burford%20Capital%20Seeks%20Director%20Of%20Case%20Management%20In%20Exclusive%20Engagement%20With%20Lateral%20Link)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/02/burford-capital-seeks-director-of-case-management-in-exclusive-engagement-with-lateral-link/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/02/burford-capital-seeks-director-of-case-management-in-exclusive-engagement-with-lateral-link/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Burford Capital, the global leader in commercial finance for the legal sector, has exclusively partnered with Lateral Link to appoint a new Director of Case Management. This strategic position, based in New York or Chicago with potential for remote work, offers an unparalleled opportunity for litigation professionals seeking to steer complex litigation cases valued over $7 billion.

The role is designed for individuals who have demonstrated significant expertise in litigation, ideally serving as heads of litigation in large enterprises, and who have a track record in managing claimant-side cases. The ideal candidate will possess not only superior communication and interpersonal skills but also a profound ability to organize and navigate the intricate demands of large litigation portfolios.

Burford Capital is renowned for its commitment to optimizing the value of legal assets, offering robust support to law firms and corporations globally. With a history of working alongside the majority of the Am Law 100 and Global 100 law firms since its inception in 2009, Burford’s dynamic team has expanded to over 170 professionals, including more than 70 lawyers, blending the resources of a large organization with the agility and creativity of a startup.

The chosen Director of Case Management will play a critical role in managing Burford’s extensive case portfolio, ensuring strategic engagement, supervising budgets, and spearheading efforts to enhance efficiency. This position calls for a collaborative spirit to work alongside business leaders and stakeholders, aiming for seamless integration of business processes and fostering strong relationships across the organization.

Burford offers a competitive compensation package, inclusive of a base salary, discretionary bonus, carried interest in litigation outcomes, and annual stock grants. The role reports directly to the Chief Investment Officer, highlighting its significance in Burford’s mission to maintain its global impact in the legal finance sector.

Burford Capital, a pioneer in legal finance, is dedicated to fostering a diverse and inclusive work environment, welcoming applicants from all backgrounds. This commitment extends to competitive healthcare benefits, a 401k matching program, and an ‘always on’ culture that thrives on rigorous thinking, clear communication, and efficient execution. For legal professionals looking to shape the future of legal finance and direct complex litigation on a global scale, this role offers a unique opportunity. Interested candidates are encouraged to apply by reaching out to Amy Langan at alangan@laterallink.com for a confidential discussion or [through our LinkedIn posting](https://www.linkedin.com/jobs/view/3812048100/?refId=ky1mCxsYSu2ffc6C4XcI0A%3D%3D&trackingId=ky1mCxsYSu2ffc6C4XcI0A%3D%3D), joining a team at the forefront of transforming the legal finance industry.

# Ex-Attorney At Top 10 Biglaw Firm Receives Short Prison Sentence For Insider Trading
## Prosecutors called the lawyer’s conduct ‘egregious.’
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onDecember 22, 2023 at 11:42 AMDecember 22, 2023 at 10:29 AM
10
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/ex-attorney-at-top-10-biglaw-firm-receives-short-prison-sentence-for-insider-trading/&text=Ex-Attorney%20At%20Top%2010%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Receives%20Short%20Prison%20Sentence%20For%20Insider%20Trading)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/ex-attorney-at-top-10-biglaw-firm-receives-short-prison-sentence-for-insider-trading/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/12/ex-attorney-at-top-10-biglaw-firm-receives-short-prison-sentence-for-insider-trading/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))


Trading on insider information never, ever ends well for anyone — especially if you’re an attorney at a Biglaw firm.

Romero Cabral Da Costa Neto, 33, of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, started working as a visiting attorney at Gibson Dunn in September 2022. Back in August, Costa was [arrested and charged with insider trading](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/ex-attorney-at-top-10-biglaw-firm-charged-with-insider-trading/), accused of accessing confidential client information from within Gibson Dunn’s internal filing system to make trades ahead of a major pharmaceutical M&A deal.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
In early November, Costa pleaded guilty to the charges, and earlier this week, he was sentenced. Costa asked for time already served plus supervised release, but instead, he was received two months in prison. The [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/2023/12/21/ex-visiting-attorney-at-gibson-dunn-sentenced-to-2-months-in-prison-for-insider-trading/) has the details:

The sentence is less than the eight months federal prosecutors had sought for Costa, which they noted was on the low end of the total offense level, in a sentencing memorandum filed Dec. 16.

Prosecutors argued that Costa’s ”personal characteristics, education, employment, and family wealth, make his conduct even more egregious” and that an incarceration sentence “deters the general public from committing these crimes as well,” in the memorandum.

According to prosecutors, among other illegal trades, Costa traded on information related to biopharmaceutical company Swedish Orphan Biovitrum AB’s acquisition of CTI BioPharma Corp (CTIC), a Gibson Dunn client. He bought more than 10,000 CTIC shares the day prior to the deal being announced publicly, and sold them the day after, making more than $42,000 in profits.

On top of being sentenced to spend time behind bars, Costa was ordered to forfeit the profits he made, as well as pay a $100 fine. He also came to an agreement with the SEC in a related civil enforcement action.

# Biglaw Firm Contemplating Transatlantic Merger
## Hopefully these two lovebirds can find a way to make it in this crazy world.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onOctober 16, 2017 at 4:54 PMOctober 16, 2017 at 4:13 PM
6
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/10/biglaw-firm-contemplating-transatlantic-merger/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Contemplating%20Transatlantic%20Merger)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/10/biglaw-firm-contemplating-transatlantic-merger/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/10/biglaw-firm-contemplating-transatlantic-merger/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Dum dum da dum… Is that wedding bells I hear? No, just another Biglaw firm looking to get in on the 2017 merger mania.

Today, Bryan Cave [announced](https://www.bryancave.com/en/news-events/bryan-cave-and-berwin-leighton-paisner-confirm-they-are-in.html) it was investigating a possible combination with U.K. firm Berwin Leighton Paisner (BLP). If this merger happens — still a big if at this stage — the new firm would be formidable with 1,500 lawyers, 32 offices in 12 countries, and a total combined gross revenue approaching $1 billion. And good news, the happy couple has already pick out its silverware, erm website, registering [www.bryancaveblp.com](http://www.bryancaveblp.com/) on October 12th.

As one might imagine, the joint statement from the firms is optimistic, and focused on the improved services they plan to provide clients:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
“If we combine, we will operate without regard to geographic boundaries,” said Bryan Cave chair Therese Pritchard in the joint statement issued by her firm and BLP. “Our firm would be one of only a handful of global firms operating in a one-firm structure with more than 500 lawyers in both the U.S. and also internationally. We will seamlessly provide counsel to clients across the globe, deliver client service at a new level and use technology and innovation to redefine efficiency in the practice of law.”

But the firms are careful not to be overly enthusiastic before their memberships have approved the merger. See, both firms have been down similar roads before, without a successful result. As [reported by](http://www.americanlawyer.com/id=1202800501086/Bryan-Cave-Big-British-Firm-BLP-Confirm-Merger-Talks) Law.com, BLP tried to merge with Greenberg Traurig last year before it fell apart, and Bryan Cave is no stranger to merger heartbreak either:

In late 2015, Bryan Cave was close to acquiring Dickstein Shapiro before a deal collapsed shortly after Christmas, leading what was left of the latter to pursue another according with Blank Rome. But Bryan Cave has a long track record when it comes to law firm combinations, having absorbed Denver-based Holme Roberts & Owen in 2012, Atlanta-based Powell Goldstein in 2009 and New York’s Robinson Silverman Pearce Aronsohn & Berman in 2002. In 2006, Bryan Cave held unsuccessful merger talks with Squire Patton Boggs predecessor Squire, Sanders & Dempsey.

With firm cultures and financials that seem to fit, hopefully these two  lovebirds can find a way to make it in this crazy world.

# High-Profile Conservative Lawyers Call Trump's Behavior Into Question, Ask Congress To Investigate
## There's now bipartisan support for further investigation of the information documented in the Mueller report.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onApril 25, 2019 at 3:15 PMApril 25, 2019 at 1:42 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/04/high-profile-conservative-lawyers-call-trumps-behavior-into-question-ask-congress-to-investigate/&text=High-Profile%20Conservative%20Lawyers%20Call%20Trump’s%20Behavior%20Into%20Question,%20Ask%20Congress%20To%20Investigate)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/04/high-profile-conservative-lawyers-call-trumps-behavior-into-question-ask-congress-to-investigate/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/04/high-profile-conservative-lawyers-call-trumps-behavior-into-question-ask-congress-to-investigate/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Photo by Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images)

The facts contained in the report reveal that the President engaged in persistent conduct intended to derail, undermine and obstruct ongoing federal investigations. In light of the longstanding Department of Justice legal opinion that a sitting President cannot be indicted, we view it as irrelevant whether there is a prosecutorial recommendation that the crime of obstruction has been committed. Instead, we believe that the President’s conduct demonstrates a flagrant disregard for the rule of law — a disregard that is in direct conflict with his constitutional responsibilities, including his commitment under oath to “preserve, protect and defend the Constitution of the United States.” …

We believe the framers of the Constitution would have viewed the totality of this conduct as evidence of high crimes and misdemeanors. Accordingly, Congress, which carries its own constitutional oversight responsibilities, should conduct further investigation.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
— an excerpt from a [statement](https://checks-and-balances.org/new-statement-from-checks-and-balances-on-the-mueller-report/) released by Checks & Balances, a group of high-profile conservative lawyers, asking Congress to [further investigate President Donald Trump](https://www.law.com/2019/04/24/conservative-big-law-veterans-raise-specter-of-trump-impeachment/) based on the conduct detailed in the Mueller report. Signatories to the statement include Professor [Jonathan H. Adler](https://law.case.edu/Our-School/Faculty-Staff/Meet-Our-Faculty/Faculty-Detail/id/83) of Case Western Reserve University School of Law, [Donald B. Ayer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_B._Ayer) of Jones Day (a retired partner, formerly of the Justice Department), [John B. Bellinger III](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_B._Bellinger_III) of Arnold & Porter Kaye Scholer (formerly of the State Department and National Security Council), [George T. Conway III](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_T._Conway_III) of Wachtell (husband of Kellyanne Conway), [Carrie F. Cordero](https://www.law.georgetown.edu/faculty/carrie-f-cordero/) of the Center for a New American Security at Georgetown (formerly of the Justice Department), [Stuart M. Gerson](https://www.ebglaw.com/stuart-m-gerson/) of Epstein Becker & Green (formerly of the Justice Department), [Peter D. Keisler](https://www.sidley.com/en/people/k/keisler-peter-d) of Sidley Austin (formerly of the Justice Department), [Marisa C. Maleck](https://www.kslaw.com/people/marisa-maleck) of King & Spalding (a former law clerk to Justice Clarence Thomas), [Alan Charles Raul](https://www.sidley.com/en/people/r/raul-alan-charles) of Sidley Austin (formerly served as Associate Counsel to President Ronald Regan), [Paul Rosenzweig](https://www.rstreet.org/team/paul-rosenzweig/) of R Street Institute (formerly of Homeland Security), and Professor [J.W. Verret](https://www.law.gmu.edu/faculty/directory/fulltime/verret_jw) of the George Mason University Antonin Scalia Law School (formerly of the Trump transition team).

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky-6344b322).

# It’s Always The Law Professors You Think It’s Going To Be
## No shockers when it comes to which professors are whining about vaccines.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onAugust 11, 2021 at 4:42 PMAugust 11, 2021 at 3:45 PM
9
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/its-always-the-law-professors-you-think-its-going-to-be/&text=It’s%20Always%20The%20Law%20Professors%20You%20Think%20It’s%20Going%20To%20Be)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/its-always-the-law-professors-you-think-its-going-to-be/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/its-always-the-law-professors-you-think-its-going-to-be/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Joe and Kathryn chat about the lawsuit against George Mason University brought by GMU Law School — better known by their unfortunately chosen name “ASSLaw” — law professor Todd Zywicki over his refusal to get vaccinated. It’s a remarkably unimpressive complaint. Cravath, in the midst of many changes, announces a new flexible office work policy based around a floating 6 remote work days per month. Could this become the new normal? And Rudy Giuliani is still broadcasting to the world that he works at Greenberg Tarurig. Maybe he means Greenberg Traurig Total Landscaping?

### [ How Will Walgreens’ Expansion Into Specialty Pharmacy Affect The Industry? ](https://medcitynews.com/2024/04/walgreens-specialty-pharmacy-drugs/)
Walgreens announced that it is expanding its specialty pharmacy offerings. Experts think that this move could yield several strategic benefits, given the higher profit margins associated with specialty medications compared to traditional drugs. # Cravath Is NOT Offering Special Bonuses, And Associates Are Pissed
## Ooof. The former bonus leader has really made its associates angry.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onSeptember 29, 2020 at 5:42 PMSeptember 30, 2020 at 8:27 AM
13
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/cravath-is-not-offering-special-bonuses-and-associates-are-pissed/&text=Cravath%20Is%20NOT%20Offering%20Special%20Bonuses,%20And%20Associates%20Are%20Pissed)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/cravath-is-not-offering-special-bonuses-and-associates-are-pissed/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/cravath-is-not-offering-special-bonuses-and-associates-are-pissed/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
It’s been about two weeks since Biglaw firms started handing out cash to associates in appreciation for all of their hard work during the pandemic. First came [Cooley](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/biglaw-fall-special-bonus-tracker-which-biglaw-firms-are-handing-out-cash-for-associates-hard-work-during-the-pandemic/), which started the COVID bonus trend in the first place. Next came [Davis Polk](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/wow-davis-polk-raises-the-bar-on-bonuses/), which blew the Cooley scale out of the water, and others firms quickly fell over themselves to match the generous scale, one by one by one by one. So many firms have matched the bonus scale that we’ve started a [bonus tracker](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/biglaw-fall-special-bonus-tracker-which-biglaw-firms-are-handing-out-cash-for-associates-hard-work-during-the-pandemic/) here at Above the Law.

All the while, we’ve been wondering: Where is Cravath? Why hasn’t the perrenial bonus leader entered the bonus fray?

Cravath has heard Biglaw’s whispers and has finally entered the COVID bonus wars — but alas, the elite firm seems to be echoing [Kirkland’s response](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/09/kirklands-not-giving-special-bonuses-and-associates-are-salty-about-it/). HA.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
That’s right, Cravath will not be offering its associates a fall bonus. Cravath, the firm whose equity partners earned $4,414,000 in profits in 2019, is going to be sitting this one out, and unlike Kirkland — which pledged to “take into account … the fall bonuses paid by any other firm” in determining its December bonuses — didn’t even commit to taking the fall bonuses into consideration in announcing its year-end bonuses.

Read the memo for yourself:



Cravath associates are understandably not thrilled by this news:

From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
It’s embarrassing that we bill so much at Cravath, but make less than our peers, especially when you consider our terrible benefits. We’re suckers.

Cravath’s bonus memo also makes no commitment that 2020 bonuses will be at least at 2019 levels. No reassurance for its associates on any level –> why say anything?

This is insulting to associates and short-sighted by the partners. It looks particularly bad not to make a similar type of commitment to what Kirkland made. It makes you think: did these guys lose a big malpractice arbitration? Do they not have enough cash on hand to make this kind of payment without doing a capital call? Goodbye #1 Vault ranking.

People come to Cravath for two reasons: the training and prestige. The Firm’s decision not to pay out COVID bonuses (at least not yet (I hope)), directly undermines the prestige factor. And that hurts associates and partners alike, which I assume the partners appreciate. Which leads me to wonder: are they hurting financially? We associates don’t know because you won’t find a partnership less transparent than this one in BigLaw.

Cravath is outright insulting their associates. They don’t even guarantee the same bonuses as last year, so they are worse than K&E.

Cravath gave associates the dick punch. No bonuses.

Ouch.

So, what do you think? Is this a sign to other firms not to match? Has Cravath given up its seat as Biglaw’s bonus leader? Feel free to sound off [by email](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=Cravath), by text message (646-820-8477), or by tweet ([@ATLblog](https://twitter.com/atlblog)). A fun or insightful response — we’ll keep you anonymous — could find its way into an update to this story.

Please help us help you when it comes to bonus news at other firms. As soon as your firm’s bonus memo comes out, please [email it to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Bonus”) or text us (646-820-8477). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky-6344b322).
